**G.L. c. 218, \u00a719**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, §19** and **G.L. c. 185C, §3**, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

**G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, §19** and **G.L. c. 185C, §3**, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a71**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 223, §1**, because the Premises at issue are located in Springfield, Hampden County, Massachusetts.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a714**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 186, §14**, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

***Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment does not require an intentional act but may arise from a landlord’s negligence or inaction, as recognized in ***Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977)**.
***Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects any requirement of intentional conduct by the landlord and holds that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment can arise from what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, so long as the disturbing condition is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct and under the landlord’s control. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not his intentions, is controlling, and it finds a violation where the landlords had notice and failed effectively to remedy the problem caused by another tenant’s use.
***Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (.relevant_excerpt: “Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises… There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

***Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1.proposition: Defendant’s conduct violated Plaintiff’s statutory and common law rights under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, and constitutes a breach of the implied covenant recognized in ***Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997)** (landlord’s failure to maintain property may amount to breach of quiet enjoyment).
***Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explicitly states that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects—including failure to maintain the property—can constitute a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, which codified the common-law implied covenant. Although the specific issue was whether a *strict-liability* lead paint violation alone suffices (the court held it does not), the case affirmatively recognizes that, where the landlord has notice or reason to know of a dangerous condition and fails to act reasonably, that failure can breach quiet enjoyment under § 14 and the implied covenant. Thus it supports the narrower proposition that a landlord’s failure to maintain property (when negligent and with notice) may amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment.
***Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’… Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord… Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

***Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: Under *Simon v. Solomon*, supra, interference with quiet enjoyment is established where a landlord’s conduct or failure to act creates conditions “so serious as to materially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.”
***Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” and, relying on prior Massachusetts cases, describes it as protection from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leased premises. The court then applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 to repeated sewage flooding, treating those conditions as an interference with quiet enjoyment because they deprived the tenant of the beneficial use of the apartment. That aligns with the proposition that quiet enjoyment is violated when the landlord’s conduct or inaction creates conditions so serious as to materially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.
***Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ — words that have little inherent meaning but a rich background in decisional law — it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.” 385 Mass. at 101–02.

***Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that failure to maintain essential services or utilities amounts to an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, including but not limited to:
***Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass..support_reasoning: The decision squarely addresses G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that a landlord’s failure to correct serious code violations—specifically including inadequate heat and hot water—constitutes an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment. The court explains that omissions such as failing to repair known defects can violate § 14 and, applying that principle, finds a violation where inadequate heat and hot water and vermin infestation substantially impaired the value of the premises. This aligns with the proposition that failure to maintain essential services/utilities is an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment.
***Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

***Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417.raw_text: ***Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)*
***Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that failure to maintain essential services or utilities amounts to an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, including but not limited to:
***Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
***Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417.support_reasoning: The case is about drug-related criminal activity in common areas and the landlord’s duty under G.L. c. 121B and the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not address failure to maintain essential services or utilities (like heat, water, electricity) nor hold that such failures constitute interference with quiet enjoyment. Instead, it focuses on security/omissions regarding third-party criminal conduct, so it does not support the utilities-based proposition.
***Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417.relevant_excerpt: "The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. ... We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. ... If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment."

***Winchester v. Miss. Valley Gas Co.*,.raw_text: ***Winchester v. Miss. Valley Gas Co.*, 321 Mass. 253 (1947)*
***Winchester v. Miss. Valley Gas Co.*,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that failure to maintain essential services or utilities amounts to an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, including but not limited to:
***Winchester v. Miss. Valley Gas Co.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Winchester v. Mississippi Valley Gas Co. concerns assessment of damages for diversion of river water and related eminent domain issues; it does not involve landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or failure to maintain utilities or essential services. There is no discussion of interference with quiet enjoyment as a leasehold covenant or statutory right, nor of utilities being shut off or inadequately maintained. Thus, the case does not support the proposition about Massachusetts decisions on failure to maintain essential services as actionable interference with quiet enjoyment.
***Winchester v. Miss. Valley Gas Co.*,.relevant_excerpt: A riparian owner, as an incident to the ownership of the land, has the right to have the natural flow of a stream come to his land and to make such use of the water as will be reasonable with respect to similar rights of all other riparian owners. Barrett v. Parsons, 10 Cush. 367. Pratt v. Lamson, 2 Allen, 275. Moulton v. Newburyport Water Co. 137 Mass. 163. Mason v. Whitney, 193 Mass. 152. Stratton v. Mount Hermon Boys’ School, 216 Mass. 83. Isbell v. Greylock Mills, 231 Mass. 233.

***Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 326 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that failure to maintain essential services or utilities amounts to an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, including but not limited to:
***Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 326 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Hemingway v. O’Brien is a criminal case about armed robbery and larceny of an automobile. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, essential services or utilities, or interference with quiet enjoyment, nor does it mention such concepts. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that failure to maintain essential services is an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
***Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien*, 326 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The defendant was tried and convicted upon an indictment charging him and one Kelly with armed robbery, and upon another indictment charging him with the larceny of an automobile. The only assignments of error argued by him are to the admission of certain articles in evidence and to the denial of his motions for directed verdicts of not guilty.

***Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that failure to maintain essential services or utilities amounts to an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, including but not limited to:
***Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the landlord’s statutory obligation to supply heat and hot water under the State Sanitary Code and holds that this obligation can only be shifted to the tenant by a written agreement. However, the court does not analyze this failure as an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14, nor does it discuss or apply the quiet enjoyment doctrine at all. Thus, while it addresses utility obligations, it does not stand as authority that failure to maintain essential services constitutes actionable interference with quiet enjoyment.
***Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

***Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that failure to maintain essential services or utilities amounts to an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, including but not limited to:
***Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The excerpt shows findings and damages for negligence, breach of the implied warranty of habitability, violations of G.L. c. 186, §14, and c. 93A, but it does not discuss a failure to maintain essential services or utilities (like heat, water, electricity) as constituting an interference with quiet enjoyment. The only explicit reference to quiet enjoyment is that it was listed in the tenant’s c. 93A demand letter, without the Appeals Court analyzing or holding that failure to provide essential services is actionable under §14 or at common law. Thus, it does not meaningfully support the specific proposition quoted.
***Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: On October 23, 1981, LeClair sent Brown a “demand letter” seeking damages and requesting relief (repairs) under c. 93A for problems relating to leaks, the January 31, 1980, flood, cockroaches, the assault, and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Brown’s agent responded by denying *980any unfair practice, claiming that the problems had been corrected and refusing to make repairs as they had been “made long ago.” An offer of $150 to settle the matter was made.

***Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. A.raw_text: ***Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 858 (1989)*
***Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. A.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that failure to maintain essential services or utilities amounts to an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, including but not limited to:
***Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. A.case_name: Home-Like Apartments, Inc. v. Architectural Access Board
***Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion concerns enforcement of Massachusetts Architectural Access Board regulations and a developer’s obligation to comply with accessibility requirements. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, essential services or utilities, or interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14 or related doctrines. Because the case neither discusses nor applies any rule about failure to maintain utilities as a breach of quiet enjoyment, it does not support the stated proposition.
***Sargent v. Tenaska, Inc.*, 27 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: A review of the transcript of the hearing before the board and its decision, in light of § 13A and pertinent regulations, shows that: (1) the five percent rule set out in the statute had been in effect for ten years when Home-Like commenced building Patriot Village; (2) Home-Like’s suggested alternatives to compliance with the applicable law were tenuous and contingent upon the possible actions of those whose interests are different from those of the board; (3) compliance to the extent required by the board will provide an obvious substantial benefit to handicapped persons; and (4) full compliance was not required by the board.

***Anderson v. Beta Realty Corp.*, 31 Ma.raw_text: ***Anderson v. Beta Realty Corp.*, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 386 (1991)*
***Anderson v. Beta Realty Corp.*, 31 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that failure to maintain essential services or utilities amounts to an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment, including but not limited to:
***Anderson v. Beta Realty Corp.*, 31 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion in Anderson v. Beta Realty Corp. (as provided) is actually a criminal drug-trafficking case dealing with suppression issues, expert testimony, prosecutorial conduct, and ineffective assistance of counsel. It does not concern landlord-tenant law, essential services or utilities, or interference with quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, it cannot be used as authority for the proposition about failure to maintain essential services constituting interference with quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.

**G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A**.proposition: Defendant’s inaction also violated Massachusetts’ habitability and safety obligations under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, **G.L. c. 239, §8A**, and the **State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000**, which collectively require landlords to maintain essential utilities including electricity in all habitable rooms.

**State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.00.proposition: Defendant’s inaction also violated Massachusetts’ habitability and safety obligations under **G.L. c. 186, §14**, **G.L. c. 239, §8A**, and the **State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000**, which collectively require landlords to maintain essential utilities including electricity in all habitable rooms.
